awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Prototyping a Multiple-Input Multiple-Output Single-Carrier Modulation Turbo Transceiver for Robust Underwater Wireless Communications.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project is enabling reliable wireless communications in several underwater technology markets which include ocean exploration and discovery, underwater recreation, fishery industry, subsea oil and gas industry, underwater environmental and infrastructure monitoring,  and military. The project aims at increasing reliability and information data rates in underwater wireless communication links by an order of magnitude over existing technologies. When applied to Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) and wireless sensor networks, the proposed technology leads to great potential in reducing operational costs, improving efficiency, reducing safety risks, and enabling new capabilities such as Internet of Underwater Things (IoUT). The development of multidisciplinary education and student training from both engineering and entrepreneurial perspectives further impacts the next generation workforce by attracting women and underrepresented groups.

The proposed project bridges the knowledge gap between Matlab post-processing and real-time hardware implementations of Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) Turbo transceivers. A MIMO transceiver transmits multiple data streams via multiple transmit elements to increase data rate, and uses multiple receive elements to improve the reliability. The past research of the principle investigator have demonstrates via ocean experiments and post processing that Turbo receiver is effective in combatting hostile underwater acoustic communication channels by utilizing advanced error-correction coding and channel equalization. The main goal of this project is to design and validate a prototype that demonstrates real-time operation of the MIMO Turbo transceiver in underwater acoustic environment, achieving 50 - 100 kilo-bits-per-second (kbps) information data rate over 1 - 10 km distance and at 99.99% reliability. This is at least an order of magnitude improvement over existing underwater acoustic communication systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This PFI-TT project translates the innovative Multiple-Input Multiple-Output Single-Carrier Modulation (MIMO-SCM) Turbo receiver technology into transmitter and receiver prototypes that achieve 50 - 100 kbps information data rate at 99.99% reliability for high-mobility platforms to communicate underwater over 1 - 10 km distances. This is 2x to 10x increase of data rate and one to two orders of magnitude improvement of reliability over most existing products. The success of this project bridges the fundamental research and technology transfer to the field. The outcomes of the project include:

1) three US patents: two granted and one pending:

  • Xiyuan Zhu and Y. Rosa Zheng, “Technologies for acoustic multiple-input multiple-Output (MIMO) transmission through a serial peripheral interface (SPI) bus,” US Patent #12,009,886. June 2024.
  • Xiyuan Zhu and Y. Rosa Zheng, “Technologies for acoustic multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) transmission through a serial peripheral interface (SPI) bus,” US Patent #12176973. Issued Dec. 24, 2024.
  • Yukang Xue, Xiyuan Zhu, Y. R. Zheng, “A new Turbo Decision Feedback Equalizer and Decoder (TDFED) for Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation,”  A nonprovisional Patent application was submitted in Jan 2025.

2) a collaboration with a small business on an SBIR phase I project;

3) a creation of a new startup company: A new startup by the Principle Investigator was created in 2023 which is dedicated to transfer the technology to practical products;

4) training of four graduate students: among those, one is a minority student and one is a female student. Two of the graduate students graduated and obtained full-time job at reputable corporations.

5) Training of six undergraduate researchers through the REU supplement: among those, two are female students and two have graduated and got full-time employment in reputable institute and corporation.

6) an innovative summer project on underwater autonomous vehicle design: The summer program supported an underwater robotics team to participate in RoboSub competitions. The project was also support in part by Lehigh University’s Mountaintop Creative Inquiry program which promotes undergraduate summer research experiences;

7) outstanding publications in refereed conference and journals: in addition to patents, the project also published 3 journal papers and 15 conference papers.

 


Last Modified: 02/19/2025
Modified by: Yahong Rosa Zheng
